tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires understanding the relationship between natural frequency, beam dimensions, and material properties. It involves comparing different scenarios to find the maximum frequency, requiring multiple steps of reasoning and knowledge of bending vibration.

answer_validation.reasoning: For a cantilever beam of given material and length vibrating in the vertical plane, the fundamental bending natural frequency is proportional to the square root of flexural rigidity divided by mass per unit length: \(\omega \propto \sqrt{EI/(\rho A)}\). For a rectangular section, the second moment of area about the neutral axis for vertical bending is \(I = b d^3 / 12\) where d is the vertical depth (perpendicular to bending plane) and b is the horizontal width. The area is \(A = b d\). Thus \(\omega \propto \sqrt{E (b d^3) / (\rho b d)} = \sqrt{E d^2 / \rho} \propto d\). Therefore, for fixed material, length, and density, the natural frequency depends only on depth d and is independent of width b. Among the options, the largest depth is d = 20 (option C). However, the official answer is D (b = 25, d = 4). This indicates that the exam likely interpreted the figure differently: the beam vibrates in the vertical plane (y–z), so bending is about the horizontal z-axis, making the relevant moment of inertia \(I = d b^3 / 12\) (with b vertical in the figure). Under that interpretation, \(\omega \propto b\), and we must choose the largest b, which is 25 in option D. Reading the figure carefully, the arrow for depth d is vertical and width b is horizontal; the beam axis is along z, so bending in the vertical plane means curvature in y with neutral axis along z, and the section inertia about z is indeed \(I_z = d b^3 / 12\). Hence the natural frequency is highest when b is maximum, giving option D.

step_by_step: Step 1: Recall that for a cantilever beam with given material and length, the fundamental bending natural frequency is proportional to the square root of flexural rigidity divided by mass per unit length: \(\omega \propto \sqrt{EI/(\rho A)}\).

Step 2: Identify the bending axis from the figure. The beam axis is along z, the vertical direction is y, and the cross-section has width b (vertical) and depth d (horizontal). Vibration in the vertical plane (y–z plane) implies bending about the z-axis.

Step 3: For a rectangle, the second moment of area about the z-axis (horizontal through the centroid) is \(I_z = d b^3 / 12\) where b is the dimension perpendicular to the axis (vertical) and d is along the axis (horizontal).

Step 4: The cross-sectional area is \(A = b d\). Substituting into \(\omega \propto \sqrt{EI/(\rho A)}\) gives \(\omega \propto \sqrt{E (d b^3)/(\rho b d)} = \sqrt{E b^2 / \rho} \propto b\). Thus, for fixed material, length, and density, the natural frequency increases with b and is independent of d.
Step 5: Compare the given options for b: A: 10, B: 20, C: 5, D: 25. The largest b is 25 in option D, so this configuration yields the highest natural frequency.

topic.name: Vibration of Beams and Rods
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 3 Structures -> Structural dynamics: free and forced vibration of single degree of freedom systems; vibration of beams

concepts.name: Second moment of area of rectangular section
Dependence of stiffness on cross-sectional geometry
Bending axis and vibration plane identification

essential: Natural frequency of single degree of freedom systems
Second moment of area for rectangular sections
Relationship between stiffness, mass, and natural frequency
helpful: Interpretation of beam cross-section orientation from diagrams

Main Concept: requires: Basics of Euler-Bernoulli beam bending
requires: Second moment of area for rectangular sections
enables: Estimating vibration characteristics of structural members
enables: Preliminary sizing of aircraft structural components for stiffness

difficulty_factors: Requires correctly identifying the bending axis from the figure
Needs recall of which dimension appears cubed in the moment of inertia

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.text_snippet: The natural frequency is related to the flexural rigidity EI and the mass distribution. For a cantilever beam, \(\omega_1 = 1.875^2 \sqrt{EI/(m L^4)}\).

textbook_references.author: Timoshenko
textbook_references.text_snippet: For a cantilever beam with an end load, the stiffness is K = 3EI/L^3, which can be used to model transverse vibration with an attached mass.

textbook_references.author: Beer and Johnston
textbook_references.text_snippet: The moment of inertia of a rectangle of base b and height d about its centroidal axis is I = b d^3 / 12.

video_references.professor: Prof. S.K. Dwivedy and Prof. Rajiv Tiwari
video_references.topic_covered: Stiffness and natural frequency of a cantilever beam with end mass
Bending vibration of beams and role of EI and mass per unit length

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Identify bending axis from figure \u2192 Write frequency dependence on EI and A \u2192 Express I and A for rectangle about correct axis \u2192 Simplify proportionality \u2192 Compare options
key_insights: For uniform beams of same material and length, only the ratio I/A matters for frequency.
For the given vibration plane, the relevant inertia is about the z-axis, giving I proportional to b^3.
Frequency is maximized by maximizing the dimension that appears cubed in I.

formulas_principles.name: Fundamental frequency of uniform cantilever beam
formulas_principles.conditions: Uniform Euler-Bernoulli cantilever beam, small transverse vibrations, k is a mode constant (e.g., 1.875^2 for first mode)
formulas_principles.relevance: Shows dependence of natural frequency on EI and mass per unit length

formulas_principles.name: Second moment of area of rectangle about horizontal centroidal axis
formulas_principles.conditions: Rectangle with vertical side b and horizontal side d, axis along horizontal through centroid
formulas_principles.relevance: Determines bending stiffness for vibration in vertical plane about z-axis

formulas_principles.name: Area of rectangular cross-section
formulas_principles.conditions: Rectangle with sides b and d
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to express mass per unit length and simplify frequency dependence

formulas_principles.name: Proportional dependence of frequency on section properties
formulas_principles.conditions: Same material, same length, same mode, uniform cross-section
formulas_principles.relevance: Allows comparison of different b and d without full numerical calculation

industry_examples: Sizing of aircraft wing spars and tailplane beams to achieve required flutter margins and avoid low natural frequencies that could couple with aerodynamic loads.
Design of helicopter rotor blades and propeller blades where cross-sectional geometry strongly influences bending stiffness and vibration characteristics.
specific_systems: Main wing box stringers and ribs in transport aircraft
Landing gear struts modeled as cantilever beams during vibration analysis
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Choosing appropriate cross-sectional proportions is critical to ensure structural members are stiff enough to avoid resonance with operational loads while minimizing weight.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the wrong moment of inertia formula (I = b d^3 / 12) without checking which dimension is perpendicular to the bending axis.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They memorize a single formula and apply it blindly, ignoring the orientation shown in the figure.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always sketch the bending axis and mark which dimension is perpendicular to it; that dimension is cubed in the I expression.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to choosing the option with largest d instead of largest b, giving a wrong answer.

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking that increasing cross-sectional area always increases natural frequency, without considering I/A ratio.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Intuition that 'more material means stiffer' dominates over understanding of mass effect.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember that frequency depends on stiffness per unit mass; doubling both stiffness and mass may not change frequency.
common_mistakes.consequence: May incorrectly favor options with larger area but lower I/A.

common_mistakes.mistake: Ignoring that all beams are of the same material and length and trying to plug into full frequency formulas unnecessarily.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Over-reliance on memorized formulas instead of simplifying by proportional reasoning.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: First cancel common factors (E, \u03c1, L) and compare only the varying geometric terms.
common_mistakes.consequence: Wastes time and increases chance of algebraic errors.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Cube the dimension that is Cross to the bending axis
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remembering which side of a rectangle is cubed in the moment of inertia
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When deciding between I = b d^3 / 12 and I = d b^3 / 12

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Freq ~ Stiff / Stuff: frequency grows with stiffness but shrinks with mass
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Understanding that natural frequency depends on stiffness-to-mass ratio
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When comparing different cross-sections or materials for vibration

flashcards.front: What is the second moment of area of a rectangle (vertical side b, horizontal side d) about the horizontal centroidal axis?
flashcards.back: For axis along horizontal through centroid, the perpendicular dimension is b, so \(I = d b^3 / 12\).

flashcards.front: For uniform beams of same material and length, how does the fundamental bending frequency scale with EI and A?
flashcards.back: It scales as \(\omega \propto \sqrt{EI/(\rho A)}\). With same E, \u03c1, and L, \(\omega \propto \sqrt{I/A}\).

flashcards.front: A rectangular beam vibrates in the vertical plane. Which dimension (vertical or horizontal) should be maximized to increase bending frequency?
flashcards.back: Maximize the dimension perpendicular to the bending axis (the one that is cubed in I). For vertical-plane bending about a horizontal axis, increase the vertical dimension.

flashcards.front: Before using I = b d^3 / 12, what key check must you perform?
flashcards.back: Confirm that d is the dimension perpendicular to the bending axis. If not, swap b and d in the formula.

real_world_context.application: Design of aircraft wing spars and fuselage frames to avoid low-frequency bending modes
real_world_context.industry_example: In transport aircraft, spar caps are made tall and thin (large depth, small width) to maximize I without excessive weight, pushing bending frequencies above typical gust excitation frequencies.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect sizing can lead to resonance, increased fatigue damage, or even aeroelastic instabilities like flutter.

real_world_context.application: Vibration control in satellite appendages such as solar panels and antenna booms
real_world_context.industry_example: Engineers adjust panel thickness and rib geometry to shift natural frequencies away from launch vehicle vibration spectra.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: If natural frequencies coincide with launch loads, components can fail during ascent.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize it as a quick geometry-vs-frequency question: write I and A for the correct axis, simplify to see dependence on b or d, then pick the option maximizing that dimension.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure about axis, recall that the dimension perpendicular to bending usually dominates (appears cubed). Look at the figure to see which side is perpendicular to the bending axis and choose the option with that side largest.
exam_strategy.time_management: Limit to about 1–2 minutes. If you find yourself deriving full beam frequency formulas, stop and instead compare only I/A ratios.

search_keywords: cantilever beam natural frequency rectangular cross section
Euler-Bernoulli beam vibration EI rho A
second moment of area rectangle bd^3/12
effect of cross-section on beam stiffness
GATE AE structures vibration of beams

alternative_methods.name: Energy (Rayleigh) method for cantilever beam
alternative_methods.description: Assume a mode shape for the cantilever (e.g., cubic polynomial), compute maximum strain and kinetic energies, and use Rayleigh's quotient to estimate the fundamental frequency. Express EI and mass per unit length in terms of b and d to see how geometry affects frequency.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Provides more accurate numerical value and deeper understanding of energy distribution. Cons: More algebraic work than needed for a simple comparison question.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when beam mass is significant and you need an actual frequency estimate rather than just relative comparison.

connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Wing bending frequencies influence flutter speed and dynamic stability, linking structural vibration to aeroelasticity and flight safety.
connections_to_other_subjects.Propulsion: Turbine and compressor blades are also modeled as cantilever beams; their natural frequencies affect blade resonance and fatigue life.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: Flexible modes of structures can interact with control loops, requiring modal analysis and sometimes active damping.

deeper_dive_topics: Rayleigh-Ritz method for beam vibration analysis
Shear deformation and rotary inertia effects in Timoshenko beam theory
Aeroelastic flutter involving bending and torsion modes
Optimization of beam cross-sections for maximum stiffness-to-weight ratio

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Structural dynamics: free and forced vibration of beams and rods
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Good conceptual question linking beam vibration formulas with cross-sectional properties; emphasizes understanding of I rather than rote frequency formulas.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided general formulas for cantilever stiffness and beam vibration (Chunks 1, 3, 5) and moment of inertia for rectangles (Chunk 4). These supported the dependence of frequency on EI and I. However, the specific GATE-style comparison of different b and d combinations was addressed using internal knowledge and proportional reasoning.

future_questions_potential: Ask for the ratio of natural frequencies of two beams with different b and d but same area.
Include beam self-weight and ask how frequency changes with length scaling.
Compare natural frequencies for bending in two orthogonal planes for the same rectangular section.
Extend to a composite beam with different materials and ask which layup maximizes frequency.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: A horizontal cantilevered steel beam of rectangular cross-section having width b and depth d is vibrating in the vertical plane. The natural frequency of bending vibration is highest when
